20110120023003.000|20110120023005.000|CC1|THE GRAVESITE FOR AT LEAST 120  
20110120023005.000|20110120023007.000|CC1|PEOPLE, SO HAVE A BIT OF RESPECT
20110120023007.000|20110120023008.000|CC1|FOR THE WRECK AND THE SITE      
20110120023008.000|20110120023009.000|CC1|ITSELF AND ALSO FOR THE MARINE  
20110120023009.000|20110120023012.000|CC1|ANIMALS AROUND IT.              
20110120023012.000|20110120023018.000|CC1|I'M GOING DOWN UNDER! HA!       
20110120023018.000|20110120023019.000|CC1|THE YONGALA WAS A               
20110120023019.000|20110120023021.000|CC1|PASSENGER AND GENERAL CARGO     
20110120023021.000|20110120023023.000|CC1|SHIP WHICH WAS HIT BY A CYCLONE 
20110120023023.000|20110120023024.000|CC1|ON A ROUTINE RUN UP THE         
20110120023024.000|20110120023027.000|CC1|QUEENSLAND COAST BACK IN 1911.  
20110120023027.000|20110120023028.000|CC1|MASSIVE WAVES CRASHED OVER THE  
20110120023028.000|20110120023031.000|CC1|DECKS, SENDING 121 PASSENGERS   
20110120023031.000|20110120023034.000|CC1|AND CREW TO A WATERY GRAVE. THE 
20110120023034.000|20110120023035.000|CC1|SHIP HAD NO SIGNAL EQUIPMENT,   
20110120023035.000|20110120023037.000|CC1|SO BACK ON LAND, THE FAMILIES   
20110120023037.000|20110120023038.000|CC1|WAITED IN VAIN FOR THE SHIP TO  
20110120023038.000|20110120023042.000|CC1|RETURN. OVER THE YEARS, THERE   
20110120023042.000|20110120023043.000|CC1|WERE MYSTERY SIGHTINGS, BUT IT  
20110120023043.000|20110120023045.000|CC1|WASN'T UNTIL 60 YEARS LATER     
20110120023045.000|20110120023047.000|CC1|THAT 2 DIVERS INVESTIGATING     
20110120023047.000|20110120023048.000|CC1|THIS WRECK DISCOVERED THE       
20110120023048.000|20110120023050.000|CC1|WORDS YONGALA ON THE STARBOARD  
20110120023050.000|20110120023053.000|CC1|BOW. OVER THE YEARS, THE CORAL  
20110120023053.000|20110120023055.000|CC1|HAS GROWN AND TOTALLY COVERED   
20110120023055.000|20110120023057.000|CC1|THE SHIP. IT HAS BECOME HOME TO 
20110120023057.000|20110120023103.000|CC1|AN ARRAY OF FLORA AND FAUNA.    
20110120023103.000|20110120023104.000|CC1|>> AMAZING. DID YOU SEE THAT    
20110120023104.000|20110120023105.000|CC1|GROUPER?                        
20110120023105.000|20110120023106.000|CC1|>> YES.                         
20110120023106.000|20110120023107.000|CC1|>> THAT HUGE ONE.               
20110120023107.000|20110120023108.000|CC1|>> THE SHIP IS MAGNIFICENT.     
20110120023108.000|20110120023111.000|CC1|IT'S ABSOLUTELY HUGE, AND NATURE
20110120023111.000|20110120023113.000|CC1|HAS MANAGED TO DECORATE IT SO   
20110120023113.000|20110120023117.000|CC1|TASTEFULLY. FABULOUS COLORS,    
20110120023117.000|20110120023119.000|CC1|GREAT FISH, SAW A TURTLE,       
20110120023119.000|20110120023122.000|CC1|SAW STINGRAYS, SEA SNAKES, TONS 
20110120023122.000|20110120023124.000|CC1|OF FISH THAT LOOKED LIKE THEY   
20110120023124.000|20110120023126.000|CC1|ALL HAD A MEETING AND DECIDED,  
20110120023126.000|20110120023128.000|CC1|"OK. YOU TAKE THE STERN, WE'LL  
20110120023128.000|20110120023129.000|CC1|TAKE THE BOW." VERY CLIQUISH    
20110120023129.000|20110120023132.000|CC1|GROUPS THESE FISH. ANYWAY,      
20110120023132.000|20110120023142.000|CC1|ABSOLUTELY AMAZING.             
20110120023142.000|20110120023144.000|CC1|I AM FINALLY IN CAIRNS.         
20110120023144.000|20110120023145.000|CC1|I'VE COME HERE MAINLY TO GO     
20110120023145.000|20110120023147.000|CC1|DIVING LIKE MOST PEOPLE DO.     
20110120023147.000|20110120023148.000|CC1|IT'S A GREAT PLACE BECAUSE THE  
20110120023148.000|20110120023149.000|CC1|OUTER REEF IS REALLY ACCESSIBLE 
20110120023149.000|20110120023151.000|CC1|AT THIS POINT, BUT LOOK AT THIS

20110120023157.000|20110120023159.000|CC1|WAY, DOWN THERE OR UP HERE, I'M 
20110120023159.000|20110120023203.000|CC1|GOING TO GET WET.               
20110120023203.000|20110120023204.000|CC1|I HAVE SEEN SOME PRETTY         
20110120023204.000|20110120023206.000|CC1|AMAZING THINGS DIVING, BUT THIS 
20110120023206.000|20110120023208.000|CC1|MAN--YOU'RE PADDY, RIGHT?       
20110120023208.000|20110120023209.000|CC1|>> YEP.                         
20110120023209.000|20110120023210.000|CC1|>> I'M MEGAN. CAN SHOW ME SOME  
20110120023210.000|20110120023211.000|CC1|EVEN STRANGER THINGS.           
20110120023211.000|20110120023213.000|CC1|PADDY IS A MARINE BIOLOGIST AND 
20110120023213.000|20110120023214.000|CC1|RUNS A COMPANY CALLED           
20110120023214.000|20110120023215.000|CC1|REEF TEACH, WHERE YOU CAN LEARN 
20110120023215.000|20110120023217.000|CC1|ALL ABOUT THE REEF.             
20110120023217.000|20110120023218.000|CC1|THIS IS ONE SMALL PART OF A     
20110120023218.000|20110120023221.000|CC1|VERY GREAT REEF.                
20110120023221.000|20110120023221.000|CC1|>> THE GREAT BARRIER REEF IS    
20110120023221.000|20110120023222.000|CC1|NOT ONE REEF.                   
20110120023222.000|20110120023223.000|CC1|>> IT'S NOT ONE REEF.           
20110120023223.000|20110120023224.000|CC1|>> IT'S MADE UP OF THOUSANDS OF 
20110120023224.000|20110120023225.000|CC1|DIFFERENT REEFS. EACH REEF IS   
20110120023225.000|20110120023227.000|CC1|SEPARATED FROM THE NEXT REEF BY 
20110120023227.000|20110120023229.000|CC1|THE HUGE SEA, AND THE SEA HAS   
20110120023229.000|20110120023230.000|CC1|GOT VERY LITTLE LIFE IN IT, BUT 
20110120023230.000|20110120023232.000|CC1|THE REEF ITSELF HAS GOT MORE    
20110120023232.000|20110120023233.000|CC1|DIFFERENT TYPES OF ANIMALS AND  
20110120023233.000|20110120023235.000|CC1|PLANTS LIVING WITHIN IT THAN    
20110120023235.000|20110120023237.000|CC1|YOU'LL FIND IN ANY OTHER MARINE 
20110120023237.000|20110120023239.000|CC1|SYSTEM IN THE WORLD. THERE'S AT 
20110120023239.000|20110120023241.000|CC1|LEAST 1,500 DIFFERENT SPECIES OF
20110120023241.000|20110120023242.000|CC1|FISH, 400 DIFFERENT SPECIES OF  
20110120023242.000|20110120023244.000|CC1|CORALS, 6,000 DIFFERENT SPECIES 
20110120023244.000|20110120023246.000|CC1|OF CRUSTACEANS, 4,000 DIFFERENT 
20110120023246.000|20110120023247.000|CC1|SPECIES OF MOLLUSKS. THE LIST   
20110120023247.000|20110120023248.000|CC1|GOES ON AND ON.                 
20110120023248.000|20110120023248.000|CC1|>> AMAZING.                     
20110120023248.000|20110120023249.000|CC1|>> AND IT'S THE ONLY LIVING     
20110120023249.000|20110120023250.000|CC1|STRUCTURE WE CAN SEE FROM THE   
20110120023250.000|20110120023252.000|CC1|MOON WITH OUR NAKED EYE, AND    
20110120023252.000|20110120023253.000|CC1|IT'S ABSOLUTELY MASSIVE, AND    
20110120023253.000|20110120023255.000|CC1|SCIENCE OVERALL KNOWS DAMN ALL  
20110120023255.000|20110120023256.000|CC1|ABOUT IT. WE KEEP FINDING NEW   
20110120023256.000|20110120023257.000|CC1|THINGS, NEW SPECIES OF THIS,    
20110120023257.000|20110120023258.000|CC1|THAT, AND THE OTHER ALL OVER THE
20110120023258.000|20110120023301.000|CC1|PLACE, AND WE'VE NAMED--THE     
20110120023301.000|20110120023302.000|CC1|LITERATURE OF MARINE            
20110120023302.000|20110120023304.000|CC1|ANIMALS HAS NAMED 372 SPECIES OF
20110120023304.000|20110120023305.000|CC1|SPONGES IN THE GREAT BARRIER    
20110120023305.000|20110120023307.000|CC1|REEF IN 1994, AND WE KNOW       
20110120023307.000|20110120023308.000|CC1|THERE'S AT LEAST A THOUSAND OUT 
20110120023308.000|20110120023311.000|CC1|THERE. AND AZT, THE BIG WONDER  
20110120023311.000|20110120023312.000|CC1|DRUG FOR AIDS, CAME FROM ONE    
20110120023312.000|20110120023315.000|CC1|SPONGE IN THE MEDITERRANEAN, AND
20110120023315.000|20110120023316.000|CC1|YET WE'VE GOT OVER A THOUSAND   
20110120023316.000|20110120023317.000|CC1|SPONGES OUT THERE. WE           
20110120023317.000|20110120023317.000|CC1|HAVEN'T EVEN NAMED A THIRD OF   
20110120023317.000|20110120023321.000|CC1|THEM.                           
20110120023321.000|20110120023322.000|CC1|>> THE GREAT BARRIER REEF IS    
20110120023322.000|20110120023324.000|CC1|ACTUALLY A HUGE LIVING          
20110120023324.000|20110120023326.000|CC1|ORGANISM. EACH PIECE OF         
20110120023326.000|20110120023327.000|CC1|COLORFUL CORAL IS IN FACT A     
20110120023327.000|20110120023329.000|CC1|TINY ANIMAL ALSO KNOWN AS A     
20110120023329.000|20110120023331.000|CC1|POLYP, WHICH HAS A STOMACH, A   
20110120023331.000|20110120023332.000|CC1|TINY MOUTH AT ITS CENTER, AND A 
20110120023332.000|20110120023334.000|CC1|RING OF TENTACLES AROUND ITS    
20110120023334.000|20110120023336.000|CC1|TOP. THESE TENTACLES ARE PACKED 
20110120023336.000|20110120023337.000|CC1|WITH STINGING CELLS THAT INJECT 
20110120023337.000|20110120023340.000|CC1|POISONOUS DARTS INTO PREY. THE  
20110120023340.000|20110120023341.000|CC1|CORAL GETS ITS COLOR FROM A     
20110120023341.000|20110120023342.000|CC1|MICROSCOPIC PLANT WHICH LIVES   
20110120023342.000|20110120023347.000|CC1|INSIDE AND ABSORBS LIGHT.       
20110120023347.000|20110120023349.000|CC1|PADDY DEMONSTRATES HOW CORAL    
20110120023349.000|20110120023350.000|CC1|CAN CHANGE COLOR, BUT VISITORS  
20110120023350.000|20110120023351.000|CC1|TO THE REEF SHOULD AVOID        
20110120023351.000|20110120023353.000|CC1|TOUCHING ANY MARINE ORGANISMS   
20110120023353.000|20110120023354.000|CC1|AS THEY CAN BE DAMAGED BY THE   
20110120023354.000|20110120023356.000|CC1|GENTLEST CONTACT.               
20110120023356.000|20110120023358.000|CC1|THE REEF IS NOW A MARINE PARK,  
20110120023358.000|20110120023359.000|CC1|AND ACTIVITIES ARE STRICTLY     
20110120023359.000|20110120023400.000|CC1|CONTROLLED TO PROTECT IT FROM   
20110120023400.000|20110120023406.000|CC1|POLLUTION OR DAMAGE. I WONDER   
20110120023406.000|20110120023408.000|CC1|IF THIS PLAYFUL FISH IS THE ONE 
20110120023408.000|20110120023422.000|CC1|I'VE BEEN LOOKING FOR.

20110120023427.000|20110120023428.000|CC1|REMEMBER THE ONE I SAID,        
20110120023428.000|20110120023429.000|CC1|ALBERT, WAS THAT ALBERT?        
20110120023429.000|20110120023430.000|CC1|>> AH, IT'S A FEMALE, A YOUNG   
20110120023430.000|20110120023432.000|CC1|FEMALE, BUT YOU GENERALLY CALL  
20110120023432.000|20110120023432.000|CC1|THEM WHEN THEY GET OLDER A      
20110120023432.000|20110120023434.000|CC1|WALLY, OK? THAT WAS A YOUNG     
20110120023434.000|20110120023435.000|CC1|FEMALE, AND IT'S USUALLY THE    
20110120023435.000|20110120023437.000|CC1|MALES THAT COME OVER AND PLAY   
20110120023437.000|20110120023437.000|CC1|WITH US BECAUSE THEY'RE THE

20110120023443.000|20110120023444.000|CC1|AWAY FROM US. THAT HAPPENED TO

20110120023458.000|20110120023459.000|CC1|>> FROM CAIRNS, I'M TAKING THE  
20110120023459.000|20110120023501.000|CC1|PLANE TO THE NORTHERNMOST TIP   
20110120023501.000|20110120023503.000|CC1|OF AUSTRALIA TO THURSDAY        
20110120023503.000|20110120023504.000|CC1|ISLAND, THE CAPITAL OF THE      
20110120023504.000|20110120023507.000|CC1|TORRES STRAIT ISLANDS.          
20110120023507.000|20110120023509.000|CC1|DISCOVERED IN 1606, THERE ARE   
20110120023509.000|20110120023510.000|CC1|OVER 100 ISLANDS IN THE TORRES  
20110120023510.000|20110120023512.000|CC1|STRAIT, BUT ONLY 17 ARE         
20110120023512.000|20110120023514.000|CC1|INHABITED. THEY HAVE BEEN       
20110120023514.000|20110120023515.000|CC1|DESCRIBED AS STEPPING STONES TO 
20110120023515.000|20110120023517.000|CC1|PAPUA NEW GUINEA, WHICH IS LESS 
20110120023517.000|20110120023518.000|CC1|THAN A MILE FROM THE

20110120023523.000|20110120023524.000|CC1|WITH A POPULATION OF ABOUT      
20110120023524.000|20110120023526.000|CC1|9,000, THE ISLANDS ARE          
20110120023526.000|20110120023528.000|CC1|POLITICALLY AUSTRALIAN, BUT NOT 
20110120023528.000|20110120023529.000|CC1|SURPRISINGLY, THE PEOPLE HAVE   
20110120023529.000|20110120023530.000|CC1|STRONG MELANESIAN AND NEW       
20110120023530.000|20110120023533.000|CC1|GUINEAN INFLUENCE. THE CEMETERY 
20110120023533.000|20110120023535.000|CC1|ALSO BEARS WITNESS TO A STRONG  
20110120023535.000|20110120023537.000|CC1|JAPANESE INFLUENCE. FOR NEARLY  
20110120023537.000|20110120023538.000|CC1|100 YEARS, JAPANESE DIVERS      
20110120023538.000|20110120023541.000|CC1|DIVED FOR PEARLS HERE, AND 500  
20110120023541.000|20110120023542.000|CC1|LOST THEIR LIVES. TOMMY IS THE  
20110120023542.000|20110120023544.000|CC1|LAST SURVIVING DIVER.           
20110120023544.000|20110120023546.000|CC1|DID YOU USED TO DIVE WEARING    
20110120023546.000|20110120023547.000|CC1|A HELMET LIKE THAT?             
20110120023547.000|20110120023548.000|CC1|>> SOMETHING SIMILAR TO THAT,   
20110120023548.000|20110120023551.000|CC1|YES. IT WAS MADE OF BRASS AND   
20110120023551.000|20110120023552.000|CC1|COPPER.                         
20110120023552.000|20110120023553.000|CC1|>> THE SUITS AND HELMETS USED BY
20110120023553.000|20110120023555.000|CC1|DIVERS IN THE 19th CENTURY WERE 
20110120023555.000|20110120023556.000|CC1|VERY BASIC, AND MANY DEATHS     
20110120023556.000|20110120023558.000|CC1|RESULTED FROM DECOMPRESSION     
20110120023558.000|20110120023559.000|CC1|SICKNESS.                       
20110120023559.000|20110120023601.000|CC1|I HEARD THAT THE JAPANESE       
20110120023601.000|20110120023602.000|CC1|DIDN'T BOMB THURSDAY ISLAND     
20110120023602.000|20110120023603.000|CC1|BECAUSE THEY HEARD THERE WERE   
20110120023603.000|20110120023605.000|CC1|SO MANY JAPANESE LIVING ON IT.  
20110120023605.000|20110120023607.000|CC1|>> YES, WELL THAT WOULD BE      
20110120023607.000|20110120023608.000|CC1|TRUE, YES.                      
20110120023608.000|20110120023609.000|CC1|>> THE PEARL INDUSTRY GRADUALLY 
20110120023609.000|20110120023611.000|CC1|DIED OUT AS PLASTIC TOOK OVER,  
20110120023611.000|20110120023612.000|CC1|BUT THERE ARE STILL A FEW PEARL 
20110120023612.000|20110120023615.000|CC1|FARMS HERE. JOHN SALTMARSH      
20110120023615.000|20110120023616.000|CC1|MANUFACTURES HIS OWN PEARLS ON  
20110120023616.000|20110120023617.000|CC1|ROKO ISLAND.                    
20110120023617.000|20110120023619.000|CC1|>> THIS IS A PEARL OYSTER.      
20110120023619.000|20110120023620.000|CC1|WELL, IT ISN'T A LIVE ONE, THE  
20110120023620.000|20110120023622.000|CC1|ANIMAL'S NOT THERE, BUT IT'S A  
20110120023622.000|20110120023624.000|CC1|PEARL SHELL. THESE ARE SOUTH    
20110120023624.000|20110120023626.000|CC1|SEA PEARLS OF COURSE. AND THE   
20110120023626.000|20110120023627.000|CC1|SECRET IS, THAT YOU TAKE A      
20110120023627.000|20110120023628.000|CC1|LITTLE PIECE OF THE MANTLE,     
20110120023628.000|20110120023630.000|CC1|WHICH IS A MEMBRANE THAT GROWS  
20110120023630.000|20110120023633.000|CC1|ON THE SURFACE OF THE SHELL.    
20110120023633.000|20110120023634.000|CC1|YOU TAKE A LITTLE PIECE OF THAT 
20110120023634.000|20110120023636.000|CC1|LIVING MANTLE, AND YOU PLACE IT 
20110120023636.000|20110120023639.000|CC1|WITH THE--WITH THE NUCLEUS IN   
20110120023639.000|20110120023641.000|CC1|AN INCISION, AND THAT PIECE OF  
20110120023641.000|20110120023642.000|CC1|LIVING MANTLE ACTUALLY GROWS    
20110120023642.000|20110120023644.000|CC1|AROUND THE NUCLEUS, AND THAT'S  
20110120023644.000|20110120023646.000|CC1|WHAT FORMS THE PEARL. AND WHEN  
20110120023646.000|20110120023648.000|CC1|YOU HARVEST IT AFTER 2 YEARS,   
20110120023648.000|20110120023651.000|CC1|YOU ACTUALLY CUT A SLOT IN THIS 
20110120023651.000|20110120023653.000|CC1|PEARL SACK THAT'S               
20110120023653.000|20110120023654.000|CC1|FORMED AROUND THE NUCLEUS, TAKE 
20110120023654.000|20110120023656.000|CC1|OUT THE PEARL, AND PUT ANOTHER  
20110120023656.000|20110120023657.000|CC1|NUCLEUS IN.                     
20110120023657.000|20110120023659.000|CC1|>> AND SO THAT SAME OYSTER WILL 
20110120023659.000|20110120023700.000|CC1|PRODUCE IN SUCCESSION?          
20110120023700.000|20110120023701.000|CC1|>> THAT ONE OYSTER WILL         
20110120023701.000|20110120023703.000|CC1|PRODUCE UP TO 4 ROUND PEARLS,   
20110120023703.000|20110120023704.000|CC1|YEAH.                           
20110120023704.000|20110120023706.000|CC1|>> REALLY? HOW MUCH WOULD ONE   
20110120023706.000|20110120023707.000|CC1|PEARL COST, COMING FROM         
20110120023707.000|20110120023708.000|CC1|SOMETHING LIKE THIS?            
20110120023708.000|20110120023710.000|CC1|>> OH, WELL, THERE'S SO MANY    
20110120023710.000|20110120023712.000|CC1|VARIABLES. I THINK THE WORLD    
20110120023712.000|20110120023714.000|CC1|RECORD FOR A SINGLE PEARL WAS   
20110120023714.000|20110120023717.000|CC1|$120,000.                       
20110120023717.000|20110120023718.000|CC1|>> WOW. HOW ABOUT YOUR RECORD?  
20110120023718.000|20110120023721.000|CC1|>> OUR RECORD IS 10,000.        
20110120023721.000|20110120023722.000|CC1|>> SO THIS IS WHERE YOU LIVE?   
20110120023722.000|20110120023724.000|CC1|NOT ON THE ISLAND?              
20110120023724.000|20110120023725.000|CC1|>> YES, YES. WE'VE LIVED ON THE 
20110120023725.000|20110120023729.000|CC1|BOAT NOW FOR NEARLY 30 YEARS.   
20110120023729.000|20110120023730.000|CC1|WE STILL HAVE A LITTLE BIT LEFT 
20110120023730.000|20110120023733.000|CC1|FROM OUR LAST HARVEST OF ROUND  
20110120023733.000|20110120023738.000|CC1|PEARLS. THERE'S A FEW BAROQUES, 
20110120023738.000|20110120023740.000|CC1|AND THESE ARE THE GEM QUALITY   
20110120023740.000|20110120023741.000|CC1|ONES.                           
20110120023741.000|20110120023742.000|CC1|>> AND IS THE DIFFERENCE THE    
20110120023742.000|20110120023746.000|CC1|SHAPE OR THE SIZE OR THE COLOR? 
20110120023746.000|20110120023747.000|CC1|WHAT MAKES IT GEM QUALITY?      
20110120023747.000|20110120023750.000|CC1|>> BECAUSE IT ROLLS IN A        
20110120023750.000|20110120023752.000|CC1|STRAIGHT LINE AND IT HAS NO     
20110120023752.000|20110120023755.000|CC1|FLAWS AND ITS 14 MILLIMETERS.   
20110120023755.000|20110120023756.000|CC1|VERY FEW PEARLS HAVE NO FLAWS AT
20110120023756.000|20110120023757.000|CC1|ALL.                            
20110120023757.000|20110120023759.000|CC1|>> AND HOW MUCH DO THESE

20110120023802.000|20110120023804.000|CC1|$5,000 TO $6,000 DOLLARS.       
20110120023804.000|20110120023809.000|CC1|>> WOW. THAT'S VERY PRECIOUS.

20110120024521.000|20110120024524.000|CC1|LEMONADE." EXCEPT IT'S GOT      
20110120024524.000|20110120024527.000|CC1|WINGS AND ANT BUTTS AND ANT     
20110120024527.000|20110120024530.000|CC1|LEGS AND VARIOUS ANT PARTS AND  
20110120024530.000|20110120024533.000|CC1|ANT EGGS. VERY REFRESHING. YOU  
20110120024533.000|20110120024535.000|CC1|SHOULD TRY IT.                  
20110120024535.000|20110120024536.000|CC1|THE FINAL LEG OF MY JOURNEY IS  
20110120024536.000|20110120024537.000|CC1|TAKING ME BACK OUT TO THE       
20110120024537.000|20110120024539.000|CC1|BARRIER REEF. I FLY FIRST TO    
20110120024539.000|20110120024540.000|CC1|LIZARD ISLAND, WHICH IS CLOSE   
20110120024540.000|20110120024542.000|CC1|TO ONE OF THE REEF'S MOST       
20110120024542.000|20110120024544.000|CC1|AMAZING DIVE SITES, THE COD     
20110120024544.000|20110120024553.000|CC1|HOLE.                           
20110120024553.000|20110120024554.000|CC1|LIZARD ISLAND IS A LUXURY       
20110120024554.000|20110120024556.000|CC1|RESORT ISLAND AND A FAVORITE    
20110120024556.000|20110120024558.000|CC1|RETREAT FOR THE VERY RICH. IT   
20110120024558.000|20110120024600.000|CC1|CAN COST UP TO $1,000 A NIGHT TO
20110120024600.000|20110120024602.000|CC1|STAY HERE.                      
20110120024602.000|20110120024603.000|CC1|THE NEXT LEG OF MY JOURNEY IS   
20110120024603.000|20110120024605.000|CC1|TO HEAD OUT TO THAT BOAT WHICH  
20110120024605.000|20110120024607.000|CC1|WILL THEN GO 2 HOURS OUT TO THE 
20110120024607.000|20110120024609.000|CC1|REEF AND TO THE COD HOLE.       
20110120024609.000|20110120024610.000|CC1|LIZARD ISLAND WAS FIRST         
20110120024610.000|20110120024611.000|CC1|DISCOVERED BY CAPTAIN COOK IN   
20110120024611.000|20110120024612.000|CC1|1770, AND WHEN HE SHOWED UP     
20110120024612.000|20110120024615.000|CC1|HERE, THE ONLY FORM OF LIFE HE  
20110120024615.000|20110120024618.000|CC1|SAW WERE LIZARDS EVERYWHERE, AND
20110120024618.000|20110120024619.000|CC1|HE SAID, "HENCEFORTH THIS SHALL 
20110120024619.000|20110120024621.000|CC1|BE CALLED LIZARD ISLAND."       
20110120024621.000|20110120024622.000|CC1|>> WELCOME TO THE GREAT BARRIER 
20110120024622.000|20110120024625.000|CC1|REEF AT THE COD HOLE. KNOWN FOR 
20110120024625.000|20110120024628.000|CC1|ALL THE POTATO COD THAT WE FIND 
20110120024628.000|20110120024630.000|CC1|HERE ON THE DIVE SITE.          
20110120024630.000|20110120024632.000|CC1|>> THE DIVES OUT TO THE COD HOLE
20110120024632.000|20110120024633.000|CC1|USUALLY TAKE ABOUT 3 DAYS, AND  
20110120024633.000|20110120024635.000|CC1|YOU DO ABOUT 4 DIVES A DAY TO A 
20110120024635.000|20110120024640.000|CC1|VARIETY OF DIVE LOCATIONS.      
20110120024640.000|20110120024642.000|CC1|THIS SITE ATTRACTS MANY         
20110120024642.000|20110120024643.000|CC1|DIFFERENT TYPES OF FISH,        
20110120024643.000|20110120024651.000|CC1|INCLUDING REEF SHARK, SNAPPER,  
20110120024651.000|20110120024654.000|CC1|CLOWN TRIGGER FISH, UNICORN, AND
20110120024654.000|20110120024704.000|CC1|LION FISH.                      
20110120024704.000|20110120024705.000|CC1|BUT THE BIGGEST                 
20110120024705.000|20110120024706.000|CC1|ATTRACTION IS THE GIANT POTATO  
20110120024706.000|20110120024708.000|CC1|COD, WHICH HAVE COME HERE TO BE 
20110120024708.000|20110120024710.000|CC1|FED FOR OVER 20 YEARS AND CAN   
20110120024710.000|20110120024721.000|CC1|WEIGH UP TO 330 POUNDS.         
20110120024721.000|20110120024722.000|CC1|THIS IS ONE OF THE GREAT        
20110120024722.000|20110120024724.000|CC1|BARRIER REEF'S MOST AMAZING     
20110120024724.000|20110120024725.000|CC1|SPECIES, AND THERE ARE STRICT

20110120024730.000|20110120024732.000|CC1|CAN FEED THE FISH BECAUSE       
20110120024732.000|20110120024733.000|CC1|FEEDING CAN CHANGE THEIR
